attributes.title: Hasbro: A Tale Of 2 Toy Stories
summary: While Mattel's business languishes, Hasbro just put up more strong quarterly results.
Hasbro has realized it is not about the toys, but about leveraging the brands.
In this era of electronic devices, branding and strategic licensing agreements have become key components of Hasbro's success.

attributes.content:
Hasbro Inc. (NASDAQ:HAS) has been around since 1923, and is a company name that most parents and kids recognize. The company makes toys, and while its main competitor Mattel (MAT) and its Barbie franchise in known for its "girl product" focus, Hasbro is known for its more male-orientated toys, such as the Transformers action figure line and all things Nerf. But it also markets under many more beloved brands, such as: Littlest Pet Shop, Magic: The Gathering, Monopoly, My Little Pony, and Play-Doh.

Back in April, I wrote an article about how Hasbro is not merely a toy story, but a brand story. The company is successfully leveraging its extensive brand portfolio globally and converting it into high-margin growth opportunities in its Entertainment and Licensing segment.

On July 20th, Hasbro reported yet another blowout quarter, with earnings coming in at $0.33, versus estimates of $0.29. Sales were hurt by the strong dollar and fell 3.8%. Had it not been for the currency effect, revenues would have been up 5%. The second quarter is not usually a big quarter for toy manufacturers, but Hasbro's inventory is well positioned for the holiday season. The shares rose more than 6% on the earnings results.

Hasbro has negotiated studio licensing agreements for blockbuster movie franchises such as Jurassic Park, Star Wars, and X-Men. Mattel, on the other hand, has struggled to boost sales of its iconic Barbie franchise. The result, over the last year Mattel has lost more than 30% this year while Hasbro has surged up more than 50%.

The recent success of Jurassic World and the relaunch by Disney (DIS) of the Star Wars franchise later this year has Hasbro on pace for a record year. And competing with Mattel where it hurts, in the girl category, Hasbro also inked a deal for the Disney Princess franchise. The release of the Disney movie Frozen officially knocked Barbie off her pedestal.

In this era of electronic toys and devices that Hasbro describes as "children getting older younger", branding and strategic licensing agreements have become critical to success. And the company seems to have the brand mix that children - boys AND girls - demand.

So let's take a closer look at the Hasbro stock using the Best Stocks Now app.

Data from Best Stocks Now app

Hasbro is a mid-cap stock in the Leisure sector, with a market capitalization of $9.9 billion. Its risk profile is Moderate. The company generates annual revenues of $4.3 billion.

Data from Best Stocks Now app

For a toy stock, Hasbro does not look cheap with its trailing P/E of 24 and forward P/E of 20. Its Value Grade is C. But as mentioned, Hasbro is transforming itself into more of a media company, linking its future success to licensing agreements instead of the traditional toy business.

Data from Best Stocks Now app

Investors used to view Hasbro as an old toy maker in an age of new higher-tech toys. It's the plot of Toy Story all over again: Woody versus Buzz. But that perception has changed, as the power of the licensing and brand franchise is being fully recognized. The stock is up almost 50% YTD, and receives a Momentum Grade of B+ and a Performance Grade of A-. Hasbro's execution is particularly impressive given the struggles of key competitors in the category.

Data from Best Stocks Now app

Out of the 4130+ stocks in the Gunderson Best Stocks Now universe, Hasbro ranks #83. Its stock grade is an A-, which gives it a Buy rating. I am long the stock.

Hasbro is an underappreciated growth story. The company's core business may be toys, but its growth business is the power of its brand franchise. That is a toy story that competitors like Mattel are not understanding. Sorry Barbie, you are missing the party.
